modules.description: Provides access to structured metadata including content type, version, standard, and namespace, along with lists of alternative content types and empty tags. Works with strings and string lists to represent document characteristics. Used to validate document formats and configure rendering based on defined standards.

Provides operations to lift values into a context, apply functions to wrapped values, and manipulate lists of wrapped values. Works with lifted values of type 'a Lwd.t and lists of such values. Enables building and transforming sequences of delayed computations, such as constructing event streams or lazy value chains.

Provides access to structured metadata including content type, version, standard, and namespace, along with lists of alternative content types and empty tags. Operates on strings and lists of strings to represent textual and structural document properties. Used to validate document formats and configure parsing rules based on defined standards.

Encapsulates delayed computations and event streams through operations on values of type 'a Lwd.t and their list counterparts, enabling function application and transformation within a wrapped context. Supports building complex chains of lazy evaluations by lifting and combining values. Allows for sequential processing and modification of wrapped data, such as creating dependent event handlers or deferred calculations. Examples include deferring database queries, chaining UI updates, or managing asynchronous data flows.

Manages document metadata and structural properties through string-based operations, enabling validation and configuration of parsing rules according to defined standards. Supports content type checks, version verification, and namespace handling, with operations on lists to manage alternative formats and empty elements. Allows for precise control over document processing by inspecting and enforcing standard-compliant structures. Examples include verifying a document's XML version or filtering out unsupported content types during parsing.

Encapsulates document metadata and structural rules, enabling format validation and rendering configuration. Supports string-based representations of content types, versions, and namespace definitions, along with lists of alternatives and empty tags. Allows checking compatibility between document structures and defined standards. Examples include verifying a document's content type against allowed alternatives or determining rendering behavior based on its version.

Creates elements from values and combines nested collections into single elements, handling both lists and arrays of elements. Works with reactive and constant attributes, and converts node structures into raw representations. Used to build and manipulate structured DOM-like elements with dynamic properties.

Tracks dynamic values that update in response to events, supporting reactive updates through signal propagation. Operates on streams and event sources, enabling real-time data flow management. Used to create interactive terminal interfaces by synchronizing user input with visual output.

Combines delayed computations, document metadata management, and element construction into a unified system for handling reactive and structured data. It operates on types like 'a Lwd.t, strings, and element collections, supporting lazy evaluation, validation, and DOM-like structure manipulation. Users can defer database calls, validate XML versions, and build dynamic UI elements with reactive attributes. Examples include chaining asynchronous updates, enforcing document standards, and generating responsive HTML structures.
